Philly Friday, 28. December 2007 22:06 IP: 10.251.126.70 Assigned to ‘A’ battery, 2/14th (4th AD)in Oct. 1969, which was at Merrill at that time. We moved to Pinder sometime in 1970. It was strange going from Nurnberg to a country town like Zirndorf. We used to go back to Nurnberg on our off times; but then we discovered that sitting on a haystack drinking liebfraumilch, smoking, and listening to CCR was a pretty good time too. I was a 13A10 but I was the Battery Commander’s driver for 6 months. I used to take the jeep out for a ride in the country with my buddies too. It was a great gig. The countryside around Pinder was beautiful. I was also in special weapons. And then I went to a gun section as the ammo carrier driver. The 4th Armored Division Headquarters was right next to our rooms. Our Division commander, Patton’s son (who was also a George) used to be driven in his open jeep, in the cold of winter, playing the role. But I know he never had to walk down on a Sunday night to get a greasy slice or two of pizza because every candy machine on post was empty and he was starving, or had to break into the ‘C’ ration storage bin because he had the munchies. OK, I admit we had it pretty good there; especially since no one was shooting at us. I actually had more fun there than I knew I was having at the time. I remember I couldn’t wait to get to zero days and be done with my two years but when that day came, it was tough leaving my friends there at Pinder. I left Pinder (and the army) in March 1971.185) Darren Stevens es2fire@comcast.netLocation:

I have never experienced true freedom until I was there, and I was G.I. (government issue: no different from a mop or a pair of boots). Zirndorf made me experience FREEDOM, Furth, Nurnberg, Munich, Graf, the big Ho, those places shape my experience along with the crazy cast of characters that make up the historic PINDER BARRACKS.

Of course the Zirndorfer Bier washed it all down well. We used to hang in the summer at the swimbat with the young german chics and the army brats. Spent alot of money on music, Rock concerts, film, and good smoke. Had some rough times in Nurnberg at times with the nationals who didn’t dig americans, but had alot of friends who took me places I otherwise would have never visited while there. Sad to see the barracks torn down too, but I believe the reason was because we just had too good of a time there in Zirndorf you know? God bless all you gunbunnies, medics, cooks, officers, nco’s, and shithead enlisted men. Don’t forget you service for America as well as the comrads in Germany who owe us a debt of gratitude.ger-christ-gal @yahoo.com:
